Abstract 
002\003\004\005\006\007\010\011\012\013\003\014\004\015\016\017\020\021\004\022\011\020\023\010\016\003\024\023\004\025\011\010\004\026\023\021\023\010\011\014\023\003\023\011\017\027\004 026\016\030\011\011\007\004\031\016\007\032\023\030\017\024\023\004\033\020\017\027\021\023\010\027\004 004 033\034\013\035\036\013\004\037\013\003 \004\022\013\003\014\035\026\016\017\004\033\034\023\003 \004\016\003\030\004\036\013\035!\011\004\033\034\023\003\014\004 023\007\021#\004\033\011\006\007\017\021\023\010\004$\024\013\023\003\024\023\004\016\003\030\004\005\003\025\011\010\006\016\021\013\011\003\004%\003\014\013\003\023\023\010\013\003\014\004 022\016\006&\016\003\014\004'\003\013\012\023\010\027\013\021\(\004 022\016\013\007\023\013 \004\022\016\013 024\034\013\(\013\020\013\003*\006\016\013\020#\021&\017#\023\030\017#\021\--./0/1/ \004,--./0,,23*\027--#\021&\017#\023\030\017#\021 004 004 
002\003\004\005\006\007\010\011\012\013\014\015\016\017\006\012\020\021\020\022\015\017\011\006\010\023\006\024\020\012\025\005\022\013\007\005\006\004\020\026\006\017\020\015\016\005\022\006 005\027\014\021\005\011\005\006 012\010\012\013\030\020\021\015\014\031\006 015\016\006 014\004\005\006 020\021\005\020\006 010\023\006 030\020\021\017\005\032\026\007\020\030\005\006 022\020\014\020\032\015\016\014\005\016\026\015\033\005\006 020\012\012\030\015\007\020\014\015\010\016\026\006 015\016\006 021\005\007\005\016\014\006 031\005\020\021\026\034\006 035\020\022\010\010\012\036\006 020\016\006 010\012\005\016\032\026\010\013\021\007\005\006 015\011\012\030\005\011\005\016\014\020\014\015\010\016\006\010\023\006\024\020\012\025\005\022\013\007\005\036\006\007\020\016\006\037\005\006\026\005\014\006\013\012\006\005\020\026\015\030\031\006\020\016\022\006\021\020\012\015\022\030\031\006 010\016\006\007\010\011\011\010\022\015\014\031\006\004\020\021\022 \020\021\005\006\014\010\006\023\010\021\011\006\020\006\011\020\026\026\015\033\005\006\007\010\011\012\013\014\015\016\017\006\007\030\013\026\014\005\021\034\006 016\006 026\013\007\004\006 020\006 007\030\013\026\014\005\021\036\006 014\020\026"\006 023\020\015\030\013\021\005\026\006 020\016\022\006 016\010\022\005\006 023\020\015\030\013\021\005\026\006 020\021\005\006 016\010\014\006 020\016\006 020\016\010\011\020\030\031\036\006 004\015\007\004\006 015\030\030\006 007\020\013\026\005\006 020\006 026\013\037\026\014\020\016\014\015\020\030\006 015\011\012\020\007\014\006 010\016\006 035\020\022\010\010\012#\026\006

016\025\011\010\023\006\023\003\021\013\011\003\023\030\004 034\023\021\023\010\011\014\023\003\023\013\021\(\004 013\027\027\017\023 \004 025\016\013\020\017\010\023\027\004 013\003\004 007\023\010\025\011\010\006\016\003\024\023\004 030\023\014\010\016\030\016\021\013\011\003\004 021\011\004 024\020\011\017\030\004 024\011\006\007\017\021\013\003\014\004 027\(\027\021\023\006\027#\004 026\023\010\023\004 023\004 021\016&\023\004 026\016\030\011\011\007\004 016\027\004 016\003\004 0235\016\006\007\020\023#\004 026\016\030\011\011\007\004 034\016\027\004 4\017\013\020\021\035\013\003\004 025\016\017\020\021\004 021\011\020\023\010\016\003\024\023\004 006\023\024\034\016\003\013\027\006\027\004 027\011\004 021\034\016\021\004 007\010\011\014\010\016\006\006\023\010\027\004 030\011\004 003\011\021\004 003\023\023\030\004 021\011\004 034\016\003\030\020\023\004 034\011 021\011\004 010\023\024\011\012\023\010\004 027\(\027\021\023\006\004 007\023\010\025\011\010\006\016\003\024\023\004 017\003\030\023\010\004 025\016\013\020\017\010\023\004 024\011\003\030\013\021\013\011\003\027 \004 B\011\004 023\021\004 016\020#\004 0;\004 025\011\017\003\030\004\021\034\016\021\004\013\003\004\016\004\027\006\016\020\020\035\027\024\016\020\023\004\026\016\030\011\011\007\004\016\007\007\020\013\024\016\021\013\011\003 \004\016\004\027\013\003\014\020\023\004\025\016\013\020\017\010\023\004 024\016\003\004\007\010\011\020\011\003\014\004C\0114\004\024\011\006\007\020\023\021\013\011\003\004\021\013\006\023\0044\(\004D0E#\004\005\003\004\007\016\010\021\013\024\017\020\016\010 \004\027\013\003\024\023\004 024\020\011\017\030\004 024\011\006\007\017\021\013\003\014\004 027\(\027\021\023\006\027\004 016\010\023\004 024\011\006\007\011\027\023\030\004 011\025\004 003\017\006\023\010\011\017\027\004 024\011\006\006\011\030\013\021\(\004\024\011\006\007\017\021\023\010\027 \004\021\016\027&\004\025\016\013\020\017\010\023\027\004\016\003\030\004\003\011\030\023\004\025\016\013\020\017\010\023\027\004\016\010\023\0044\(\004 003\011\004\006\023\016\003\027\004\016\003\004\016\003\011\006\016\020\(#\004\031\011\010\023\011\012\023\010 \004\013\021\004\034\016\027\0044\023\023\003\004\007\011\013\003\021\023\030\004\011\017\021\004\021\034\016\021\004 026\016\030\011\011\007\004\031\016\007\032\023\030\017\024\023\004\013\027\004\011\025\021\023\003\004\017\027\023\030\004\025\011\010\004F\027\034\011\010\021\004C\0114\027G\004\021\034\016\021\004\010\023=\017\013\010\023\004 020\011 010\023\027\007\011\003\027\023\004 021\013\006\023\004 025\010\011\006\004 021\034\023\004 024\020\011\017\030\004 024\011\006\007\017\021\013\003\014\004 027\(\027\021\023\006\027\004 004

034\023\021\023\010\011\014\023\003\023\011\017\027\004 023\003\012\013\010\011\003\006\023\003\021\027\004 004\004 005\003\004 016\004 026\016\030\011\011\007\004 024\020\017\027\021\023\010 \004 \004\\024\034\004\024\016\003\0044\023\004\017\027\023\030\0044\(\004 021\034\023\004 L\0114\022\010\016\024&\023\010\004 021\011\004 021\023\020\020\004 021\034\023\010\004 016\004 024\011\003\024\023\007\021\004 011\025\004 021\034\023\004 0377\022%\035IQ\032\004 027\024\034\023\030\017\020\023\010\004 013\027\004 \004\017\027\013\003\014\004J/KP\004 004  004\006\023\016\003\027\004 004 004\013\027\004\021\034\023\004 004\016\003\030\004 004\013\027\004\021\034\023\004 033 002!\015\0056'\0327\022\005\002!\004\002\015\004  005\031'\0377\022\005\002!\004 004 017\0064\023\010\004\011\025\004\003\011\030\023\027 004 1\004 017\0064\023\010\004\011\025\004\021\016\027 004\027\020\011\021\027\004\007\023\010\004\003\011\030\023\004 004 017\0064\023\010\004\011\025\004\013\003\013\021\013\016\020\020\(\004\016\027\027\013\014\003\023\030\004\021\016\027&\027\004\007\023\010\004\021\016\027&\004\027\020\011\021\004 004 015\016\024\021\011\010\004\011\025\004\030\016\021\016\004\010\023\007\020\013\024\016\021\013\011\003\004\013\003\004\026"\015$\004 004 Q\023\010\024\023\003\021\016\014\023\004\011\025\004\003\011\030\023\027\004 004\010\023\030\017\024\023\030\004\027\007\023\023\030\004 10E\004 015\013\014#\004/\004\027\034\011\\021\034\023\004\024\011\006\007\016\010\013\027\011\003\004\011\025\004\021\034\023\004 033\011\006\007\016\010\013\027\011\003\004\011\025\004\020\011\003\014\023\027\021\004C\0114\004\024\011 006\007\020\023\021\013\011\003\004\021\013\006\023\004J\0235\007\023\010\013\006\023\003\021\004/K#\004 10#22 D#,D-0#@1 D20 DT0 D-0 00 0 10 0 026\016\030\011\011\007 0377\022 0377\022%\035IQ\032 
002 002 
  
025\016\013\020\017\010\023\004 010\023\024\011\012\023\010\( \004 021\034\023\004 4\023\003\023\025\013\021\004 024\011\006\023\027\004 016\021\004 021\034\023\004 024\011\027\021\004 011\025\004 0235\023\024\017\021\013\011\003#\004>\013\021\034\011\017\021\004\021\034\013\027\004\017\007\007\023\010\0044\011\017\003\030 \004\021\034\023\004C\0114\004\024\011\006\007\020\023\021\013\011\003\004\021\013\006\023\004 015\013\014#\004/#\004 
002 
C Scheduler for Task Re-execution slow tasks failed tasks data location-aware data-local map A Simulation 1: Performance of LATE-VPR longest 
020\011\005\014\005\021\006 020\030\013\005\006

B Simulation 2: Performance of CKP-H and CKP-Q

007\010\011\007\023\010\004\016\020\014\011\010\013\021\034\006\004\021\011\004\025\013\003\030\004\010\023\016\020\004\027\020\011\\017\003\003\013\003\014\004\021\016\027&\027 010\023=\017\013\010\023\027\004\025\016\013\020\023\030\004\021\016\027&\027\004\021\011\004\010\023\027\021\016\010\021\004\025\010\011\006\004\027\024\010\016\021\024\034#\004\005\003\004\021\034\013\027\004\010\023\027\023\016\010\024\034\004\\023\004 \004\013\003\004\\034\004\025\016\013\020\023\030\004\031\016\007\007\023\010\004\021\016\027&\027\004\030\011\004\003\011\021\004 In this section we focus on load distributions generated by Algorithm 1 We depict the minimum and the maximum load for random graphs Table II power-law graphs Table III Smallworld graphs Table IV and AS graphs Table V For random graphs power-law graphs and small world graphs the maximum load is at most  even for small neighborhood sizes The load distribution on AS graphs is much worse the minimum load is usually zero and the maximum load is typically much higher than the average load and it only declines for large and randomized neighborhoods Table II R EGULAR GRAPHS L OAD DISTRIBUTION Neighborhood Min Load Max Load hop neighborhood In this section we study the load distribution under the assumption that the balls do not originate at a random node of the graph We assume that the origins are chosen using a like distribution  with a parameter  where is the standard Zipf distribution This is a heavy-tail distribution that is often used to model the access distribution for web pages 25 The relati v e probability of a request for the most popular page is proportional to  We only present the results for AS graphs see Figure 2 and regular graphs see Figure 3 in this paper Figure 2 shows that for both neighborhoods and the average maximum load average taken over 100 simulations is still for AS graphs for all values of For  the average maximum load is still around for  Figure 3 exemplarily shows that the behavior for the other graph classes is similar with different values of  In this section we consider the load distribution generated by Algorithm 2 It is assumed that a sequence of jobs can originate at the same node of the network We did simulations for all four graph classes again with  Our simulations show that the maximum Table VI C ORRELATION BETWEEN DEGREE LOAD FOR AS GRAPHS Neighborhood Corr Neighborhood Corr

 We only depict the results for AS graphs see Figure 4 and regular graphs see Figure 5 in this extended abstract The results for AS graphs show that for the maximum load is still close to  Our simulations for the regular graphs in Figure 5 and the other graph classes gures omitted due to space considerations show that they can even tolerate larger values of without seeing any noteworthy increase in the maximum load compared to the results of Algorithm 1 In Section III we de“ned the as a random graph property De“nition 3.4 In the case of the vertices neighborhood and the random vertices neighborhood the randomness comes from the choice of neighbors among all neighbors that will be used for the load balancing Our theoretical analysis shows that the load distribution is very smooth for balanced graphs In this section we study the correlation between the maximum load and the value of  Again we are only able Figure 5 Regular Graphs avg maximal load for Algorithm 2 for the AS graph again averaged over simulations The vertices neighborhood has for all choices of smaller values than the random vertices neighborhood A comparison with Table V shows that the maximum load decreases with the maximum value of  Table VIII shows the minimum maximum and median value of averaged over simulations for randomly generated regular graphs The vertices neighborhood has again for all choices of smaller values than the random vertices neighborhood Nevertheless the maximum values for the randomly generated regular graphs are that low that they have nearly no impact on the maximum load please compare with Table II which can also be observed for powerlaw graphs and smallworld graphs VI O PTIMIZATIONS In the last section we observed that for regular graphs power-law graphs and for small world graphs all neighborhood types achieve a good load balance even for small values of  Unfortunately in the real-world case of AS graphs these neighborhoods overload some data centers see Table V Especially in the case of the simple hop neighborhood the maximum load is very large The reason for the overload is that some nodes are in the neighborhood of very many data centers they are in many sets o that they are the target of many load balancing actions see Figure VI Another drawback of our approach in the last section is that the nodes have to request the load of all nodes in the corresponding neighborhood This can contain   or even many more vertices in the case of the simple hop neighborhood In this section we rst deal with the second problem and consider an approach that reduces the number of load requests per ball or customer Then we consider two approaches called and  both building

in which node occurs which is similar to reducing the degree of the underlying graph Here our goal is to reduce the number of load balancing actions per ball We consider a variant of Algorithm 1 Ball randomly chooses nodes in the set and is allocated to the bin with minimum load In the case of ties several bins with minimum load one of them is chosen at random The results for are shown in Figure 6 Results for are omitted since the maximum load is very large between and  Thinning protocol for node with parameter and not from from In the previous section we saw that small values of result in a very poor load distribution Here our goal is to try to reduce the degree of the nodes so that small values of are suf“cient for having a small maximum load The thinning protocol considers all nodes with a high degree occurring in many sets in a random order To reduce the degree of these nodes we consider Algorithm 3 for one of these nodes  We try to take out the sets with  as long as the sets are not empty or until the degree of is smaller than a threshold value  The sets are considered in a random order too In Figure 7 and Figure 8 we show our results for and  both for the vertices and the random vertices neighborhood The gures depict the load improvement decrease for the maximum load  axis for compared to the maximum load with the same values for and for two values of  The simulations show that for small values of  the maximum load can be decreased considerably by thinning whereas the effect is negative for larger values of  The explanation is that for small the algorithm is able to pre-select the good neighborhoods by neglecting overloaded nodes while for larger the number of choices for the algorithm is decreased

Figure 8 AS graph thinning parameter and a Relative change for vertices neighborhood b Relative change for random vertices neighborhood 1 3 Select node 5 6 7 8 9 10 11 Choose 13 and a vertices neighborhood b random vertices neighborhood Figure 10 AS graph reducing parameter and a vertices neighborhood b random vertices neighborhood requirement of moving huge amounts of data between customers and data centers as well as intra data centers makes it much more dif“cult to balance the load as customers will prefer to keep their data close to their own facilities In this paper we have shown that standard load balancing strategies work well for many classes of networks but that they are also failing for the most important one the Internet modeled by AS graphs Therefore we have introduced strategies which remove parts of the pressure from the most loaded nodes by building implicit overlay networks The practical applicability of these strategies is that they help to understand and solve the facility location problem for cloud providers R EFERENCES  P  Berenbrink A Brinkmann T  Friedetzk y  and L Nagel Balls into bins with related random choices in

Reducing protocol with parameter  Set of the nodes with the highest edge count 2 i.u.r 4 all with all with i.u.r 12 The reducing protocol Algorithm 4 tries to reduce the degree of the nodes with the highest degree by connecting their neighbors to non-neighboring nodes with a smaller degree Let be a node connected to one of the high-degree nodes Then will be connected to the closest node that is not one of the high-degree nodes In Figures 9…10 we show our results for and  both for the vertices and the random vertices neighborhood Again the gures depict the improvement depicted as percentaged decrease in the maximum load for  compared to the maximum load for same values for and  For and and the vertices neighborhood we see a large decrease of the maximum load for very small values of  Reducing did not improve the maximum load for larger values of  The improvement is larger for than for  We do not get an improvement for the random vertices neighborhood except for and  VII C ONCLUSION Cloud computing is turning form being compute centric only to being additionally data driven Nevertheless the Figure 9 AS graph reducing parameter
